There is no way to satisfy this request given the definition of the function (the requirement that the last chunk cannot exceed previous chunk sizes). If we pick split size of 2, that would require 6 chunks. If we pick split size of 3, that would give us 4 chunks. Numpy avoids this problem by requiring the split size to be divisible by the dim size:
np.split(np.arange(0,11), 5) ValueError: array split does not result in an equal division

Personally I'd prefer we just have functions that follow numpy semantics, but given we already have this function we should probably relax the "smaller" constraint here and return chunks of size [2, 2 , 2, 2, 3].

body:
There is no way to satisfy this request given the definition of the function (the requirement that the last chunk cannot exceed previous chunk sizes).  If we pick split size of 2, that would require 6 chunks.  If we pick split size of 3, that would give us 4 chunks.  Numpy avoids this problem by requiring the split size to be divisible by the dim size:
`
np.split(np.arange(0,11), 5)
ValueError: array split does not result in an equal division
`

Personally I'd prefer we just have functions that follow numpy semantics, but given we already have this function we should probably relax the "smaller" constraint here and return chunks of size `[2, 2 , 2, 2, 3]`.
